persona.name: Maria Elena Dominguez

occupation.title: Certified Nursing Assistant (CNA) / Part-time line cook (weekends)
occupation.organization: Medical clinic and private home-care agency (weekday shifts); family-run taqueria pop-up and occasional weekend shift at a Mexican restaurant
occupation.description: Maria Elena works full-time as a CNA at a busy outpatient clinic and for a home-care agency doing 1–2 evening calls per week. Her role includes direct patient care: bathing, dressing, toileting, feeding, taking vitals, helping patients transfer and ambulate, charting in basic EHR fields, and communicating with nurses and family members in Spanish and English. She is skilled at patient lifting and uses safe-body mechanics. She also picks up weekend shifts as a line cook at a neighborhood taqueria and helps with a family pop-up food stand for extra income. Responsibilities: prepare high-volume simple Mexican dishes (salsas, shredded meats), manage a small prep station, maintain kitchen sanitation, order basic supplies for the pop-up, and occasionally handle cash. Skills and expertise: bilingual patient communication, CPR/Basic Life Support certified, wound dressing basics, infection control, safe lifting and transfer, basic EHR data entry, kitchen line cooking, food safety (ServSafe basics), time management across split schedules, conflict de-escalation with anxious patients and families. Typical difficulties: balancing long hours, physical fatigue from lifting and standing, occasional frustration with low wages and limited advancement opportunities, scheduling conflicts between clinic needs and weekend food work.

persona.residence: East Los Angeles, Los Angeles County, California, USA
persona.education: Some college: Attended East Los Angeles Community College. Completed a state-certified CNA (Certified Nursing Assistant) program and several continuing-education workshops in patient lifting, basic phlebotomy, and infection control. High school diploma earned in Guadalajara, Mexico prior to immigration. Has taken sporadic night classes in business basics and Spanish-to-English medical interpretation but did not complete an associate degree due to work and family responsibilities.
long_term_goals: Stabilize finances and build a small emergency fund to feel secure without relying on others.
Finish an accredited associate degree in nursing (LVN/LPN route) within the next 5 years and eventually study to become a registered nurse (RN).
Buy a modest two-bedroom condo or townhouse in a safer neighborhood of Los Angeles so she can stop renting and have a place to host family.
Become a reliable source of support for her younger siblings — help pay for a niece/nephew's college if possible.
Develop a side business around food (authentic Mexican tortas and catering) that she can run evenings/weekends.
Improve English-to-medical-terminology fluency to advance at work and take on mentorship roles.
Learn basic accounting and small-business marketing to properly register and scale a food venture.
Travel back to Mexico to reintroduce her mother to the coastal town she grew up in and reconnect with childhood friends.
Retire without debt and have a small savings cushion for health and leisure.
Gain enough confidence to run for a community board or neighborhood council to advocate for healthcare worker rights and immigrant services.

style.general_description: Warm, practical, and straightforward. Speaks in a compact, efficient way at work but becomes more animated and storytelling-oriented with family and friends. Uses Spanglish naturally; code-switches mid-sentence when an English technical term is easier ("la patient had low blood pressure, le dimos saline").
style.accent_and_voice: Spanish-accented Californian English — soft consonants, vowel-splitting on words like "patient" and "nurse." When stressed, syllables shorten and she speaks faster. Laugh has a breathy, quick trill; she often punctuates stories with a sharp exhale.
style.mannerisms: Tends to tuck hair behind her ear when thinking, rubs her thumb and forefinger together when anxious about money, uses hands a lot while telling family stories, places a hand on a patient's arm for reassurance. Slight forward lean when listening, maintains consistent eye contact in professional settings but softens it with elders.
style.register_and_politeness: Polite and deferential with elders and supervisors, direct and efficient with peers. Uses formal Spanish terms when addressing older relatives ("usted") but is casual with younger coworkers. Can be blunt about logistics ("I need that chart by 3 p.m.").
style.dress_and_grooming: Workwear: scrubs (navy blue), comfortable sneakers, minimal jewelry (small hoop earrings), hair tied back in a low bun. Off-shift: practical, bright colors, embroidered blouses, comfortable jeans, and an apron for cooking. Keeps nails short and clean for hygiene.
style.digital_style: Smartphone-first communication. Uses WhatsApp for family groups, Facebook to stay in touch with community events, and Instagram to follow food accounts. Uses emojis liberally in casual messages and shares voice notes frequently instead of long texts.
typical_phrases: "Hold on, I gotta check the chart."

traits: Practical and solution-oriented — focuses on what can be done now.
Moderately introverted in unfamiliar groups but warm and storytelling with close friends and family.
Duty-driven with a strong sense of responsibility toward family and patients.
Steady and patient under routine stress but has a low tolerance for unfairness and bureaucracy.
Resourceful — finds workarounds when resources are scarce (e.g., networking for shifts, bartering food prep help for repairs).
Emotionally expressive with family; more guarded with supervisors about personal struggles.
Loyal to a small circle of friends and coworkers; protects that circle actively.
Ambitious in a cautious way — wants to advance but is highly risk-averse due to financial responsibilities.
Detail-oriented in tasks that affect others' well-being (medication schedules, patient hygiene).
Prone to worry about money and long-term security, which sometimes leads to insomnia or irritability.

openness.description: Moderate. Open to new foods, experiences, and practical learning (e.g., classes) but prefers familiar cultural traditions and proven solutions.

conscientiousness.description: High. Punctual for shifts, meticulous in following care protocols, keeps household budget spreadsheets, reliable for family obligations.

extraversion.description: Below average. Comfortable in small groups and family gatherings, not drawn to big parties. Gains energy from short, meaningful interactions rather than long networking events.

agreeableness.description: Moderately high. Compassionate and cooperative, especially with patients and family; will stand firm if she perceives injustice.

neuroticism.description: Slightly elevated. Experiences worry about finances and future, occasional spells of brooding, but generally manages with routines and social support.

interests: Authentic Mexican home cooking — mole verde, carnitas, chiles rellenos, slow-cooked birria.
Street food culture — exploring new taquerias and food trucks in Los Angeles.
Soccer (fútbol) — follows Liga MX and some MLS, roots for Club América (family tradition).
Family gatherings and holiday celebrations — preparations and hosting.
Simple DIY home repairs and repainting small rooms.
Streaming telenovelas and Spanish-language dramas on streaming services.
Short weekend trips to the beach (Malibu or Ventura when possible).
Listening to ranchera, boleros, reggaetón and modern Mexican pop playlists while cooking.
Podcasts about true crime and human-interest stories in Spanish.
Watching medical dramas (Scrubs, Grey's Anatomy) occasionally for entertainment and professional curiosity.
Following local community Facebook groups for housing, jobs, and pop-up markets.
Gardening small potted herbs — cilantro, oregano, rosemary.
Practicing new recipes and adjusting family recipes to local ingredients.
Photography with her phone, especially food photos for social media.
Learning phrases in English medical vocabulary via short YouTube clips.
Volunteering occasionally at a free clinic when time permits.
Bargain hunting at local flea markets for kitchen tools and ceramic plates.
Collecting family recipes in a small handwritten notebook.
Attending a local Catholic church sometimes for community events and quinceañera-style celebrations.
Watching soccer matches with friends at neighborhood bodegas or bars.
likes: Strong, black café de olla or café con leche in the mornings.
Crunchy fresh tortillas warmed on a comal.
A clean, well-organized patient room with natural light.
Short, efficient work shifts with clear expectations.
Text/voice notes from family in the morning to feel connected.
When managers acknowledge her extra effort with a simple 'gracias' or small scheduling flexibility.
Neighborhood bodegas that know her order and keep it ready.
Discounts and community resource programs for healthcare workers.
Low-traffic busier shifts where she can move at a steady pace.
Listening to her mother tell family stories while she cooks.
Wearing a comfortable pair of sneakers that still look tidy.
Salsa verde that isn't too spicy but full of tomatillo flavor.
Sharing a dish with coworkers at shift change.
Empathetic patients who say 'thank you' and mean it.
Seasonal farmer's markets for fresh produce.
Small celebrations for patient milestones (e.g., returning home).
Using a well-organized checklist before leaving a shift.
Finding unexpected extra cash in an old coat pocket.
The smell of cilantro and grilled onion in a taco shop.
Being invited to family celebrations and feeling trusted.
dislikes: Rude supervisors who micro-manage without explanation.
Late paychecks or unexpected schedule changes without notice.
Patients' families who are aggressive or accusatory.
Wasting food or ingredients — hates throwing away produce.
Overly clinical hospital rooms with no personal touches.
Long bureaucratic phone trees when trying to access services.
Pretense or people who act superior because of education.
Extremely spicy food that masks other flavors.
Public shaming of coworkers or gossip at work.
Being stereotyped as "just" a caretaker or kitchen worker.
Cold, soggy tortillas or stale chips.
Telemarketer calls during meal prep or right before a shift.
Broken public transit that makes her late.
Unreliable friends who promise help and don't show up.
Expensive boutiques that cater only to tourists.
Long, complicated job applications that require time off work.
People who refuse basic COVID/flu precautions around vulnerable patients.
Paperwork that duplicates data entry she already completed in EHR.
Prices that jump dramatically in her neighborhood (gentrification effects).
Talking down to someone for an accent or imperfect grammar.
media_and_tech_preferences: Smartphone-first: reads news and watches short videos on her phone.
WhatsApp for family coordination and quick voice notes.
Facebook groups for local events and second-hand household items.
Instagram to follow food influencers and small local restaurants.
YouTube for recipe tutorials and quick medical-skill refreshers.
Streaming Netflix shows in Spanish and Spanish-subtitled English shows.
Prefers short-form videos (under 10 minutes) for learning new tasks.
Uses Google Maps to find taquerias and check transit times.
Avoids long Twitter threads; prefers direct messages or comments.
Occasionally buys inexpensive kitchen tools and scrubs on Amazon.

beliefs: Hard work and reliability will pay off even if progress is slow.
Family obligations come first — family celebrates together and helps one another.
Education (formal or vocational) is a reliable path to better opportunities.
Healthcare workers deserve better pay and more respect for the emotional labor they provide.
Immigrants contribute enormously to the economy and culture of the U.S.
Speaking two languages is a practical advantage and a cultural treasure.
Religious rituals and community gatherings preserve family history and identity.
It's important to teach younger family members both Mexican traditions and American practicalities.
Good food is a form of love and a way to bind generations together.
You should save a bit from every paycheck even if it's small — the habit matters.
Neighbors are an extension of family in urban immigrant neighborhoods.
Public services (transport, clinics) should be accessible to non-English speakers.
Finding joy in small moments (a patient smile, a successful dish) sustains you through long weeks.
Respecting elders is non-negotiable, even when opinions differ.
Being visible and vocal about unfair treatment at work can lead to small but meaningful changes.
It's possible to be proud of Mexican roots and take pride in being American-adjacent without contradiction.
Mental health is important, and it's okay to seek counseling or community resources when overwhelmed.
Practical skills like money management, cooking, and driving open doors as much as formal education.
Government bureaucracy is frustrating, but there are advocates and community organizations that can help navigate it.
People should pay more attention to preventive health than waiting until something is severe.
Voting is important, even if local elections feel small; they affect schools, transit, and community resources.
Childcare is incredibly expensive; supporting young parents is critical for community stability (she says this even though she is single and child-free).
People who claim 'pull yourself up by the bootstraps' often ignore systemic barriers.
Small neighborhood businesses deserve support because they reinvest in the community.
Pride in one’s work matters — she finds dignity in caregiving and cooking even if society underpays it.
Language should not be a barrier to accessing quality healthcare.
Cultural foods should be adaptable — using local ingredients is fine, but preserving core flavors matters.
Debt can be a heavy burden; avoiding unnecessary loans is prudent.
She believes in second chances — both for people who made mistakes and for systems that can be reformed.
skills: Bilingual fluency: native Spanish, functional to strong English (medical and conversational).
Certified Nursing Assistant (CNA) — patient hygiene, ADLs (activities of daily living), vitals, basic charting.
Basic phlebotomy training (community course) and experience assisting nurses with specimen collection.
CPR and Basic Life Support (BLS) certified and comfortable in emergency stabilization routines.
Safe patient handling and transfer techniques (body mechanics, gait belts).
Medication administration awareness (knows names and schedules; does not administer unless delegated).
Basic EHR navigation and data entry (scheduling, vitals logging, shift notes).
Cooking at scale: preparing sauces, rice, braises, and maintaining a line; plating and food-safety best practices.
Basic bookkeeping for the pop-up (tracking cash, simple ledger in Excel or paper notebook).
Time management across split schedules (clinic shifts + weekend kitchen).
Interpersonal communication and de-escalation with upset family members.
Practical household maintenance: patching drywall, painting, basic plumbing fixes, replacing light fixtures.
Driving in urban traffic, knowledge of local transit routes and schedules.
Social media basics for small business promotion — posting photos, simple captions, using hashtags.
Negotiation skills for shift trades and securing better hours from managers.
Event logistics for small pop-ups: permits basics, ordering supplies, coordinating volunteers.
Basic nutrition knowledge and modifying meals for diabetic patients when instructed.
Fluent in culinary knife skills and meat shredding techniques for Mexican dishes.
Comfortable giving short bedside teachings about hygiene and medication timings in Spanish.
Can read and follow regulatory checklists (OSHA/Cal-OSHA basics and clinic infection control).

general: Keeps two phone alarms: one for wake-up and one labeled 'Check schedule/shift swap' to avoid missed shifts.
Saves receipts in a small accordion folder for monthly budgeting and tax prep.
Brings homemade food to work to control costs and share with close coworkers.
Starts conversations with older patients by asking about their hometowns in Mexico to build rapport.
Arranges rides for elderly patients when clinic transit is unreliable.
Offers to take on extra short shifts when a coworker has a family emergency (and expects the same trust in return).
Uses voice notes on WhatsApp for family coordination rather than typing long messages.
Switches off social media during busy work periods to remain focused on patients.
When stressed, hums a familiar ranchera tune to self-soothe during breaks.
Always carries hand lotion and a small pack of bandaids in her bag.

morning: Wakes at 5:45 a.m. on clinic days; checks WhatsApp for family messages and confirms any ride arrangements.
Quick shower, ties hair back, puts on scrubs, and eats a bowl of oatmeal or leftover rice with fried egg.
Grabs a thermos with coffee and packs a small container of fruta and a sandwich for the day.
Leaves by 6:30 a.m. to catch the 7:00 a.m. bus or drive if carpooling with a coworker.
workday: Arrives 15 minutes early to do a quick handover and prepare her station.
Starts with cleaning and organizing patient rooms, takes vitals, documents on the EHR.
Uses lunch break to eat, check family messages, and occasionally run a short errand (pick up a part for the pop-up).
Helps new CNAs with practical tips she learned on the job; takes pride in mentoring.
Finishes charting before leaving and confirms any follow-up tasks for the oncoming shift.
evening: If working at the clinic, returns home around 5:30–6:30 p.m., changes, and checks on family via phone.
If she has a weekend kitchen shift, she preps ingredients in the evening, marinates meats, and sets up a checklist.
Sometimes attends an evening ESL or business class once a week (online or at the college) when finances allow.
Winds down by watching a short telenovela episode or chatting on the phone with her mother.
Avoids heavy screens an hour before bed, prefers a podcast or music while folding laundry.
weekend: Works a 9 a.m.–4 p.m. kitchen shift either Saturday or Sunday for extra income.
Helps her mother or an aunt with grocery shopping or errands on the other day.
Visits the local mercado for fresh produce and special ingredients.
Meets close friends for soccer-watching or to trade recipes and kitchen tips.
Helps with family pop-up food events, organizes supplies, and sometimes prints simple flyers.

physical_health: Generally good physical health; strong from manual work and frequent walking.
No chronic illnesses formally diagnosed, though she occasionally experiences lower back pain from patient lifting and long standing shifts.
Receives annual flu shots and keeps vaccinations up to date; hesitant about newer vaccines but follows clinic policy.
Mild seasonal allergies (hay fever) and occasional asthma-like wheeze when exposed to heavy kitchen smoke.
Normal BMI range but experiences occasional fatigue tied to variable sleep with split shifts.
Dental history: has some fillings, schedules dental cleanings when she can afford them.
mental_health: Occasional anxiety about finances and future plans — experiences sleepless nights before major bills.
Has experienced brief periods of low mood after long stretches of overtime; recognizes signs and leans on family for support.
Open to counseling in principle but worried about cost and stigma; would prefer a Spanish-speaking counselor or community clinic.
Uses practical coping strategies: brisk walks, music, talking with her mother, and cooking comfort foods.
medical_history_and_access: No major surgeries. Minor appendectomy at age 17 (in Mexico) with uncomplicated recovery.
Has experienced job-related minor injuries (kitchen burn/scald, muscle strain) and used employer-provided urgent care.
Accesses a community clinic for primary care and relies on employer health benefits for basic coverage when employed full-time.
Has not had continuous health insurance at all times due to gaps between jobs and immigration paperwork complexities.
medications_and_allergies: Allergic to penicillin (mild rash as a teenager) — informs providers and avoids unless allergy is re-tested.
Occasional over-the-counter use of ibuprofen for muscle aches and antacids for heartburn after heavy meals.

relationships.name: Rosa Dominguez
relationships.description: Lives in a modest apartment in the same neighborhood. Traditional, warm, and the keeper of family recipes. Maria Elena speaks with her daily by phone or WhatsApp voice notes. Rosa came to the U.S. later and struggles with some English; they are close and exchange practical and emotional support.

relationships.name: Javier Dominguez
relationships.description: Lives with a cousin and works in construction. Maria Elena helps him with job leads and sends money occasionally. They have a joking, bickering dynamic but are protective of each other.

relationships.name: Abuela "Lupita" (deceased)
relationships.description: A central figure in family stories; taught Maria Elena many recipes and the importance of community. Maria Elena still keeps Abuela's small embroidered cloth in her kitchen.

relationships.name: Cristina Vega
relationships.description: A trusted confidant at work. They trade shifts and babysit tasks for each other. Cristina is often the voice of practical advice about unionization and training classes.

relationships.name: Miguel Santos
relationships.description: They met through mutual friends; he is single as well. They have dated casually for the last two years but are both cautious about commitment because of finances and schedules. Relationship is low intensity — they go to soccer games or cook together occasionally. Maria Elena is single and has no children.

relationships.name: Employer: Eastside Clinic & HomeCare Co.
relationships.description: Supervisors and nurses who rely on her practical skills. Some supportive managers; occasional friction with those who don't respect clinic constraints.

relationships.name: Community network
relationships.description: Neighbors, church acquaintances, and the taqueria owner who provide informal childcare referrals, craft swaps, and shift tips. She is active in a neighborhood WhatsApp group for safety alerts and local opportunities.

relationships.name: Legal/immigration advisor (pro bono)
relationships.description: A community legal aid volunteer who helps Maria Elena understand residency and paperwork options; has been helpful with one major application process.

other_facts: Born in Guadalajara, Jalisco, Mexico; moved to Los Angeles with her family at age 12.
Speaks Spanish at home and with older relatives; primarily uses English at work with medical terms interspersed.
Has been single for the past three years; values independence but is open to a stable relationship.
No children and no plans for children in the immediate future due to financial considerations and career focus.
Has a small golden locket with a photo of her grandmother that she wears to work under her scrubs.
Keeps a handwritten recipe book passed down from her mother and grandmother; adds notes about local ingredient substitutions.
Once organized a small fundraising dinner for a coworker with unexpected medical bills; used her pop-up contacts and personal time.
Learns best by doing — prefers hands-on classes rather than long lectures.
Is meticulous with color-coded lists: pink for bills, green for food inventory, blue for career tasks.
Is careful about credit: has one credit card used sparingly to build credit history and pays it off monthly when possible.
Has experienced mild workplace discrimination (being overlooked for a training spot) and raised it informally with her manager.
Has a reliable circle of three close friends she calls weekly; larger social circle is looser.
Owns a used 2010 sedan shared with her brother for errands and weekend markets; car payments are a significant monthly expense.
Enjoys small rituals: Sunday phone call with her mother, making a fresh pot of coffee before a long shift, and labeling containers for the week.
Memorable life event: the first time she assisted in sending a previously immobile patient home after rehab; felt profound pride.
Tries to send a small amount of money home monthly to support family members still in Mexico.
Has moderate student loan debt from the CNA program and some unpaid community college fees.
Often trades meals for services among family and friends (e.g., she cooks dinner in exchange for help with car maintenance).
Has a small collection of music CDs from her teens that she treasures for sentimental reasons; occasionally plays one at home for nostalgia.
Is an active member of an informal neighborhood aid group that coordinates food and rides for elders.
Was once featured in a local community newsletter for running a successful pop-up taqueria booth at a neighborhood festival.
Knows several local clinic managers by first name; built this network by reliably covering shifts.
Had an early job as a dishwasher in a family restaurant where she learned basic line cooking and knife safety.
Has a recurring dream about opening a small cozy eatery combining family recipes with a modern twist.
Her favorite non-work item is a battered cast-iron comal inherited from her grandmother, used for tortillas and searing.
She keeps emergency cash hidden in her apartment in case of sudden car troubles or an unexpected fine.
She once helped translate for a non-English-speaking patient during a crucial hospital meeting and felt recognized afterward.
Has an approachable but firm bedside manner that patients often praise on satisfaction surveys.
Collects practical household items from thrift stores — good knives, ceramic bowls, and small kitchen gadgets.
Remembers childhood summers helping harvest vegetables in her grandmother's backyard, which shaped her palate and food memory.
Has started a small Instagram account to showcase her food pop-up; follower count is modest but steadily growing.
Is careful about social media privacy — rarely posts photos of family members without asking first.
Is learning to use a basic budget app but still relies on her physical receipt folder for month-end reconciliation.
Once declined a short-term high-risk job (overnight caregiving for a challenging patient) because it jeopardized her daytime clinic schedule; felt guilty but resolute.
Keeps an emergency contact list taped inside her kitchen cabinet for easy access.
